channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Suspect in Paris Attacks Is Said to Have Trained With Al Qaeda in Yemen
item.description: The suspect, Saïd Kouachi, 34, spent “a few months” training in small arms combat, marksmanship and other skills.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: Chérif Kouachi, left, 32, and his brother, Said Kouachi, 34, who are suspected in a deadly attack on a satirical newspaper in Paris.

item.title: North Korea Appears to Show Progress in Developing Missile-Launching Submarine
item.description: A research group that focuses on North Korea said satellite imagery showed what appeared to be launching tubes on a North Korean submarine.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Passengers Offer Sharply Differing Accounts of Rescue From Burning Ship
item.description: One passenger rescued in waters off Greece last week told of “chaos.” Another said “everything worked.”
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Provocative Books Tap a Mood of Profound French Anxiety
item.description: Even before the attack on Charlie Hebdo, a futuristic novel and a nostalgic essay had set off intense debate.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:description: The novelist Michel Houellebecq stopped promoting his book "Submission," after the attack on Charlie Hebdo on Wednesday.

item.title: News: Updates on Search for Suspects
item.description: As the manhunt continued, France extended its highest level terror alert to Picardy, a region north of greater Paris.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Letter From Europe: No Safety for Christians in the Mideast
item.description: For decades, Christian communities in the Middle East have dwindled, and an acceleration of this trend is fundamentally rewriting the region's demography.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Survivors Retrace a Scene of Horror at Charlie Hebdo
item.description: As witnesses recounted the massacre at the French satirical newspaper, details emerged of a routine day turned violent.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Police officers guarded the street next to the office of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo in Paris on Thursday.

item.title: Manhunt in France for Charlie Hebdo Attack Suspects Continues
item.description: As French citizens mourned their dead, the authorities were carrying out an intense search for the brothers suspected of attacking a Paris newspaper.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: The Men Behind the Cartoons at Charlie Hebdo
item.description: According to those who knew them and followed their work, the four cartoonists who were killed Wednesday represented a radical, crude and vital strain of French culture.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: Slain French Police Officer Becomes Symbol of Protests
item.description: Along with “I Am Charlie,” protesters adopted the slogan “I Am Ahmed” — after Ahmed Merabet, the officer killed outside the Charlie Hebdo office, whose parents were from North Africa.
item.dc:creator: By AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Sri Lankans Vote on Whether to Keep Leader Who Crushed Insurgency
item.description: People turned out in high numbers for an election that will decide the fate of President Mahinda Rajapaksa, who has been in office for nearly a decade.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and DHARISHA BASTIANS
item.media:credit: M. A. Pushpa Kumara/European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: A security guard at a polling station in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Official Is Removed From Post, and, Again, Salacious Details Flow
item.description: While the report from the state-run news agency Xinhua on the dismissal of the Nanjing party chief, Yang Weize, provided little detail, other Chinese news outlets are filling in the gaps.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Yang Weize, the former Communist Party secretary of Nanjing who is under investigation, at a running event in the city on Jan. 1.

item.title: Merkel Says Moscow Must Show Tangible Progress to Ease Ukraine Crisis
item.description: After pro-Russia hackers claimed responsibility for closing websites, the German chancellor said that sanctions would be lifted only amid clear cooperation.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY and ALISON SMALE

item.title: China Wants Taxes Paid by Citizens Living Afar
item.description: A longtime law, widely ignored, requires individuals and companies to pay domestic taxes on income earned outside the country.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: A Beijing street. The top income tax bracket in China is 45 percent and takes effect on incomes over $12,900 a month, a much lower level than in most Western countries.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: U.S. Charter Airline Cited for Neglecting Cargo of Macaques From China
item.description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture said Air Transport International failed to provide food and water for more than 24 hours to the crab-eating macaques it flew to Houston from Guangzhou on Dec. 7.
item.category: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: A monkey is injected with an experimental solution in a laboratory in Guangzhou.

item.title: World Briefing: China: North Korean Soldier Dies
item.description: A North Korean soldier who fled into China and killed four Chinese citizens in late December has died after being injured during an arrest attempt by Chinese security forces, according to reports by Chinese state news organizations.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Two Brothers Suspected in Killings Were Known to French Intelligence Services
item.description: The slaughter raised questions about how Chérif Kouachi, so well-known to the police for so many years, and Said, his brother, managed to conceal their intentions.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: Chérif Kouachi, left, 32, and his brother, Said Kouachi, 34, who are suspected in a deadly attack on a satirical newspaper in Paris.

item.title: Monterrey Journal: A Bus Takes a Local Route to Fighting Mexican Corruption
item.description: Born through a mix of frustration, satire and savvy, the Corruptour is a free one-hour ride led by young activists hoping to stir a political awakening with five trips per weekend.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Corruptour bus, which visits sites linked to corruption in Monterrey, Mexico, is decorated with caricatures of politicians.

item.title: One Suspect Surrenders in Attack on French Newspaper; Two Others at Large
item.description: Hamyd Mourad, 18, suspected in an assault on the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, walked into a police station northeast of Paris and gave himself up. The other suspects are two brothers, Said and Chérif Kouachi.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: Cherif Kouachi, left, 32, and his brother, Said Kouachi, 34, who are suspected in a deadly attack on a satirical newspaper in Paris.

item.title: World Briefing: Gambia: Ex-Head of Guards Led Coup Attempt, Government Says
item.description: Gambia’s government accused a former head of its presidential guard on Wednesday of leading an attempt last week to oust President Yahya Jammeh.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
